column4: Hi. I had a system running flawlessly on 8.04, Decided to upgrade to 8.10. FAIL - the upgrade looked like it went fine, but upon reboot, I get a message: Kernel Panic - not syncing: VFS: Unable to mount root fs on unknown block(0,0)
repost from above
but if I choose an older kernel, I can get it to boot
but I have no control in X
that error has been documented years ago with many ubuntu updates
so you are familiar with the solution ?

iirc usually it's due to grub trying to access wrong partition uuid so check out what's the uuid of your /boot and then modify grub menu.lst to point to the correct partition. if the error appears already before grub menu then you have propably crap in MBR and just need to rewrite mbr with correct info
yeah, I checked that, root=(0,1)- is correct, boots with older kernels
boot to rescue mode on cd, mount your file systems and check /dev/disk/by-* directories and their contents and fstab contents
What am I checking for ?
and after that check if menu.lst has correct uuid (the long string of dashes, letters and numbers)
in grub/menu.lst The root UUID of the failing kernel option is the same as all the other (older semi-working) kernel options
ok, and is the line above it that only says "uuid blahblahblahblah" the uuid of the boot partition you see in fstab?
yes, the other one I see is the swap

ok, then i suggest you boot to rescue mode from the cd and run grub to update mbr and everything to ensure it's set up correclty. if that doesn't work then i can't remember what the error could be. the last time i ran to that error was with ubuntu 5 and 6
ew. ok thx
hey! I found the solution my first problem. I had to manually make an initrd img file with sudo update-initramfs -c -k 2.6.27-11
ah so initrd was the culprit for wrong partition info... great that you found the problem :-)
the initrd.img file didn't exist at all!
ah well that explains a lot. it's really odd if the updater hasn't generated a new initrd at all...
yeah. it is odd. But apparently I'm not the first one with this issue. Than god for the internets
